title: 104_hr3659
content: The Act titled "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996" modifies a long-term contract regarding the Tongass National Forest by adding a new section for contract modifications in 1996. The Act "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996" introduces definitions for terms like board feet, contract, contracting officer, mid-market criteria, and proportionality. The Act "Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996" introduces definitions for terms like board feet, contract, contracting officer, mid-market criteria, and proportionality. It also addresses the transition from high volume stands to low volume stands in timber harvesting, with the purchaser being defined as the Ketchikan Pulp Company. Congress acknowledges the contract between the Forest Service and the purchaser for harvesting timber from the Tongass National Forest in Alaska, emphasizing the need for a pulp mill or similar facility for permanent operation. A pulp mill in southeast Alaska is essential for creating year-round, high-paying jobs, utilizing low-grade wood, and maintaining a stable economy. The purchaser plans to improve the mill environmentally and operationally, with $200 million in total capital expenditures, including $25 million already invested. A 15-year contract extension is necessary for amortizing these improvements. The purchaser of a pulp mill in southeast Alaska plans to make environmental and operational improvements with a $200 million investment, including $25 million already spent. The city of Ketchikan heavily relies on the mill for employment, and the purchaser aims to maintain a long-term commitment to the area, including utilizing local workforce and suppliers. The management planning process for forest resources in southeast Alaska aims to ensure sustainable timber production while protecting other forest uses like tourism, fishing, and recreation. Compliance with environmental laws and commitment to exploring new technologies for timber utilization are key priorities. The national interest in southeast Alaska is served by maximizing timber use, ensuring proper stewardship of publicly owned assets in the Tongass National Forest, and balancing multiple use interests to enhance forest health and economic growth. This is achieved through fostering domestic forest product markets and modifying contract terms. The contract is modified to extend the term by 15 years from June 30, 2004. The contract now includes a plan for timber volume, location, and schedule for the purchaser. Timber volume requirements are set at 962,500,000 board feet in 5-year increments. The Forest Service will provide the purchaser with 192,500,000 board feet of timber annually until March 1, 1999. The purchaser must maintain a supply of timber to harvest this amount each year. Additionally, the contracting officer must ensure the construction of roads by the purchaser in advance of the 5-year operating period to facilitate orderly harvest. The Forest Service will provide the purchaser with 192,500,000 board feet of timber annually until March 1, 1999. The purchaser must maintain a supply of timber to harvest this amount each year. The contracting officer shall perform appraisals and designate rates for the increments of timber to be provided, ensuring they do not disadvantage the purchaser. Proportionality will be measured by management areas and acres. The contract allows the purchaser to convert or replace their pulp mill with a facility producing other value-added products using pulp logs. The unilateral termination clause is eliminated, and any further modifications require mutual agreement between the Forest Service and the purchaser. The Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996 mandates modifications to contracts within 45 days of enactment. The contracting officer must update the contract text accordingly. Additionally, provisions not modified must be adjusted to align with the changes. Transition timber supply terms are also addressed. The Environmental Improvement Timber Contract Extension Act of 1996 requires contracts to be modified within 45 days of enactment. Timber volume requirements are adjusted to meet the annual target of 192,500,000 board feet per year.
